title: ISIS Implements New Weapon Of Destruction As Coalition Forces Begin Offensive
text:
ISIS Implements New Weapon Of Destruction As Coalition Forces Begin Offensive "... loud blast ..." Share on Facebook Share Tweet Email Email Print Advertisement - story continues below 
The war against ISIS took a deadly turn recently, after jihadists began using armed drones to lead attacks against coalition forces, according to a CBS report released Monday . 
As a new ISIS propaganda video shows, jihadists have begun mounting drones with what appear to be mortar shells and bombs, which are then dropped on unsuspecting victims below. 
One such victim was Iraqi TV correspondent Abdul Hameen Zebari, who was wounded in a drone strike as he traveled with Iraqi forces in Mosul. Advertisement - story continues below 
“Was there a flash of light, did you hear the explosion?” asked CBS News foreign correspondent Charlie D’Agata. 
“It was a loud blast,” said Zebari. “I fell down on my side.” 
“I knew what it was because seconds earlier the soldiers started shouting, ‘drone, drone, drone,'” he continued. Advertisement – story continues below 
Even worse, these sort of drones have been used to guide car bombs and truck bombs through Mosul’s winding streets, straight to Iraqi checkpoints and troop positions. 
Discussing the matter D’Agata, Iraqi Federal police commander General Ali al Lami said these new drone attacks require extra vigilance from his troops. 
“A car bomb can destroy a unit, a truck bomb can destroy a brigade,” he said. Advertisement - story continues below ‘Mad Dog’ Mattis Takes Only Three Hours Of Rest Before Returning To Work 
Although the U.S. military claims it has weapons capable of disrupting the control of such drones, effectively rendering them useless, al Lami said he has not received any. 
While this new component is certainly troubling for those fighting the war against ISIS, coalition forces have been making steady gains against the terrorists for quite some time. 
In the four months since the battle for Mosul began, an estimate 3,000 to 5,000 ISIS fighters have been killed and only about 2,000 remain in the embattled city. 
As it currently stands, about 750,000 civilians are trapped in western Mosul under ISIS control and reports of health concerns are on the rise after local hospitals were shutdown. 
“Even before the hospitals were closed, locals had to pay Daesh sums of money they couldn’t afford,” said one employee from Al-Jamhuri hospital. 
A renewed offense against ISIS in the city could see their total defeat sometime soon, as coalition forces launched their newest offensive against the jihadists Sunday. 
Departing on his first trip to Baghdad as U.S. Defense Secretary, James Mattis noted he would be assessing the situation. 
“I need to get current on the situation there, the political situation, the enemy situation and the friendly situation,” said Mattis, speaking with reporters in Abu Dhabi. 
“We’re going to make certain we’ve got good shared situational awareness of what we face as we work together, fight alongside each other to destroy ISIS. That’s the point about going in there,” he said. What do you think? Comment below and share. Scroll down to comment below. Advertisement Popular Right Now
